One hundred and sixty-five students at the Johns Hopkins University will receive aid under the Civil
Works Administration plan to help
moneyless but deserving students
continue their studies at least until
June.
These figures were revealed at a
meeting attended by Harry Greenstein, state CAVA administrator, and
the presidents of 17 universities and
colleges in the state.

Thomas is to be with us again this year, this time on
the occasion of the Liberal Club Conference on March
2nd and 3rd. Of all the front-line fighters and uncompromising idealists who have crossed our limited
horizon, Mr. Thomas has been among the most outstanding. Three years ago he addressed the student
assembly and spoke with such quiet sincerity and yet
such vigorous and forceful persuasiveness that one
had difficulty in realizing, for the moment, that here
was the man who had been spoken of with bated
breath as the "socialist menace". ,
If the socialist cause could boast more Norman Thomases the problem of American society would
be much farther on its way. Politics, conjointly,
would begin to take on that aura of purity which attaches to the man who pays his own expenses for the
most part in a presidential campaign.

Juan Martinez Realizes Ambition
In Entering Hopkins Last Week

Wherein Managing Editor

Proposes S;
Acting Peruvian Consul Had Dreamed Of Pursuing Medlution For All Our Woes
ical Career At University; Compares North AmerEditor, THE NEWS-LETTER:
can Education To That Of Argentina
Sir:

The greatest desire of a lifetime
came true when Juan Ricardo Martinez entered the Johns Hopkins
University last Thursday, for since
childhood this native of Argentina,
South America, who is acting consul of Peru in Baltimore, has held
the fondest hopes of coming to the
Hopkins to study.
"And that is why I was so happy
when I began work at the Hopkins",
Mr. Martinez said, after telling the
interviewer how his professors at
the University of Buenos Aires, his
father, and others, all told him the
best place in America to study medicine is at the Hopkins.
To Graduate In

1935

The young Peruvian consul is attending classes at Homewood and,
if everything goes well, will be graduated with the undergraduate class
of 1935. He has fulfilled all but a
few of the requirements for medical
school, he says, and is at present
taking English writing, chemistry,
and mathematics.
He wants to be able to enter the
Hopkins School of Medicine in the
fall of 1935. That will be the realization of a childhood dream for as
long ago as he can remember Juan
Ricardo Martinez has wanted to
come to Baltimore to study medicine
at the institution which, in his own
native country, he says, is recognized as the world's greatest medical center.

government, is based almost exactly
upon the French Elysee plan.
French professors are to be found
to a great degree, too, in the Argentine universities, he said.
In commenting on the differences
between American and South American students the Peruvian consul
smilingly said: "The students are
more organized in America—and it
should be that way. But in South
America, where the students actually govern the universities, there
are many factions which are brought
about by differences in political
opinions." Of course, he agreed
with the interviewer, undergraduates should have the right to think
as they wish, to express their own
opinions on political affairs, but
these differences in opinions should
not disrupt the organized student
body.
Choose Own Teachers

Mr. Martinez claims that Argentina, of all the South American
countries, is far more advanced educationally. He pointed out that
the higher education system, which
is exclusively maintained by the

American students aren't as
lucky as those in Argentina for, as
Mr. Martinez pointed out, the students in the South American country by popular vote select professors proposed for the faculty by the
dean. Three capable men are proposed and the students pick the one
or two they like best.
Mr. Martinez is one of the two
foreign students entered in the
February class, Lloyd Roberts, who
transferred from the University of
Wales, began work here last week,
too.
Eighteen students are registered
in the mid-year group. This number is four less than that of February, 1933. Nine are enrolled in
the College of Arts and Sciences;
five, School of Engineering; four,
School of Business Economics.

As You
Were

For The
Freshman

(February 8, 1922)
Now that the exams are over, the
Student Council rule requiring all
Freshmen to take part in some campus activity will be strictly enforced
. . the Lehigh swimming meet tomorrow will produce some brilliant
performances when the visitors try
to avenge a three-point defeat
meted out to them by the Blue Jays
last year. . . Many of the most important colleges on the eastern coast
are sending entries to the indoor
track meet which is being sponsored
by the Hopkins. It will be the biggest event of its kind ever witnessed in Baltimore . . .
* * *
(February 8, 1929)
Universities from many parts of
the country are sending representatives to the lacrosse coaching school
which Dr. Van Orman will conduct
here. As a result of the wide popularity the game is gaining, Georgia Tech, Massachusetts State, Oregon State, and the University of
Pennsylvania, have decided to study
the Hopkins method of coaching lacrosse . . . The home dribblers are
looking forward to a hard fight with
The league-leading Loyola Jesuits.
Although Hopkins was able to hand
them a defeat last year, the prospects this year are rather dim . . .
Student journalists at Lehigh pick
ten leading figures in the news
world: Herbert, Hoover (P. S.—
This was before the stock market
crash), Calvin Coolidge, Charles
Lindbergh, Prince of Wales, Alfred E. Smith, King George, Richard E. Byrd, Frank Kellogg, George
(Babe) Ruth, and Henry Ford. ..

In order to introduce the mid-year
freshman class to the various campus activities, THE NEWS-LETTER
lists the following organizations and
their respective leaders:
STUDENT COUNCIL — The
governing body of the undergraduate school. It consists of nine men,
apportioned among the four classes.
Edward H. Sadtler, president.
THE STUDENT ACTIVITIES
COUNCIL — The governing body
for non-athletic activities.
It
awards a Varsity Seal to those individuals who have served for three
years in any one of these activities.
Theodore S. Stern, president.

It has, been generally characteristic of the men
of socialistic sympathies who have operated on this
campus that they have been blessed with good ideas
and creditable ideals. For the most part they have
been worth listening to and have been conducive to
the intellectual uplift of the other students.
But equally characteristic has been a notorious
lack of any decent means of propagandizing. Rabid
blatancy has been the cause of antagonizing more conservatives than, probably, any other single phase of
the liberal movement. We have rather deplored the
fact that this has not come home to the liberalizers
and social reformers; they might have had much more
success with the reactionary group which seems to
predominate on all campuses.
Since we hold this view it may be readily imagined that we read with relief that Mr. Norman

At the football games of Rochester cheering is
done only by freshmen. Silence is considered a mark
of culture, which shows disinterestedness, control of
emotions, and an intellectual, non-partisan viewpoint—
(Is 'at so!)
The strangle hold in dances has been banned at
the University of Colorado. An appeal was sent to
society girls to refuse to dance with a young man who
failed to observe the ruling.
The Tower introduces us to a new motto:
Do right and fear no man;
Don't write and fear no woman.
At Utah University there is a frosh who is 75
years old. (Just one of the boys!)

NOBODY'S BUSINESS
By WILLIAM DE WOLFF

(1.

HAVING waited for several weeks for a chance
to see Dr. Robinson without success, I stopped at his
office again on Thursday, which was a more auspicious moment. Dr. Robinson was not immediately
visible for he was buried under a mass of papers.
Before I could ask, he commented upon the office,
and added triumphantly,"I can find anything,though".
And during the course of conversation, he proved
his point.
HE RECEIVED his A.B. at the University of
Chicago in 1898, and was a member of the third class
to be graduated. He holds the record at that stronghold of knowledge for being the youngest graduate,
for he was only seventeen when he received his first
degree. From 1898 until 1901 he was a fellow in
Greek and then went abroad for two years. He received his Ph.D. in 1904.
HE HAS taught a variety of subjects, including
Greek and Latin, as well as the history of the Greek
and Romans. Even now, while he is known for his
popular history of art course, he is teaching Greek
literature. He is an indefatigable worker, and besides teaching, running expeditions, and lecturing, he
has written a number of books, including several
translations. To date he has published sixteen volumes. He has published a series of books, now in
its eighth volume, concerning the excavations at
Olynthus. He plunged into a mass of books and
brought out the last volume.
o—o
OF COURSE, Dr. Robinson's chief concern now
is his trip to Olynthus. He is sailing February 24,
and at present he is anxiously opening every letter to
ii;crdrim.r a nice contribution.

He has lectured to the Freshman history class,
and also at the assemblies, where he made quite an impression with his slides of the ancient Greek bath
tubs. He is quite an authority on said articles.
Besides all his activities and accomplishments,
he is quite a linguist, for he speaks Turkish, Arabic,
a smattering of Chinese and Japanese, besides Latin,
Greek, German, and French.
0-0

YOU PROBABLY have seen Dr. Robinson playing tennis, and he is veritably a champion. At Syracuse last summer he won a championship, in a competition open to students and faculty. He also enjoys playing bridge and chess.
On this campaign to Greece Dr. Robinson hopes
to excavate sufficient material to make Olynthus a
real Greek Pompeii. He will return June 16.
0-0

A Scottie trotted unconcernedly into the sacred
stacks the other day, but was not rejected, although
several undergraduates were. Tsk, tsk.

The list of scholarships and fellowships available in .the School of
Higher Studies of the Faculty of
Philosophy has been released by the
president's office and includes stipends in zoology, Semitics, Latin,
Greek, political science, chemistry,
archaeology, education, and other
subjects.
Applications for these
awards may be secured from the
registrar's office and must be on file
with the president by the first of
March.

Student Advisors
Requested By J. E. A.
Students interested in voluntary
social service and able to devote one
night a week to the advising of girls
and boys in social, athletic, and educational activities are being requested by the Jewish Educational
Alliance, 1216 East Baltimore
Street. The alliance is a combination of settlement and community
center and has neighborhood
branches in four sections of the city.
Those interested in this type of
work are urged to consult with Gustave Bisgyer, executive director,

Thomas is to be with us again this year, this time on
the occasion of the Liberal Club Conference on March
2nd and 3rd. Of all the front-line fighters and uncompromising idealists who have crossed our limited
horizon, Mr. Thomas has been among the most outstanding. Three years ago he addressed the student
assembly and spoke with such quiet sincerity and yet
such vigorous and forceful persuasiveness that one
had difficulty in realizing, for the moment, that here
was the man who had been spoken of with bated
breath as the "socialist menace". ,
If the socialist cause could boast more Norman Thomases the problem of American society would
be much farther on its way. Politics, conjointly,
would begin to take on that aura of purity which attaches to the man who pays his own expenses for the
most part in a presidential campaign.

Juan Martinez Realizes Ambition
In Entering Hopkins Last Week

Wherein Managing Editor

Proposes S;
Acting Peruvian Consul Had Dreamed Of Pursuing Medlution For All Our Woes
ical Career At University; Compares North AmerEditor, THE NEWS-LETTER:
can Education To That Of Argentina
Sir:

The greatest desire of a lifetime
came true when Juan Ricardo Martinez entered the Johns Hopkins
University last Thursday, for since
childhood this native of Argentina,
South America, who is acting consul of Peru in Baltimore, has held
the fondest hopes of coming to the
Hopkins to study.
"And that is why I was so happy
when I began work at the Hopkins",
Mr. Martinez said, after telling the
interviewer how his professors at
the University of Buenos Aires, his
father, and others, all told him the
best place in America to study medicine is at the Hopkins.
To Graduate In

1935

The young Peruvian consul is attending classes at Homewood and,
if everything goes well, will be graduated with the undergraduate class
of 1935. He has fulfilled all but a
few of the requirements for medical
school, he says, and is at present
taking English writing, chemistry,
and mathematics.
He wants to be able to enter the
Hopkins School of Medicine in the
fall of 1935. That will be the realization of a childhood dream for as
long ago as he can remember Juan
Ricardo Martinez has wanted to
come to Baltimore to study medicine
at the institution which, in his own
native country, he says, is recognized as the world's greatest medical center.

government, is based almost exactly
upon the French Elysee plan.
French professors are to be found
to a great degree, too, in the Argentine universities, he said.
In commenting on the differences
between American and South American students the Peruvian consul
smilingly said: "The students are
more organized in America—and it
should be that way. But in South
America, where the students actually govern the universities, there
are many factions which are brought
about by differences in political
opinions." Of course, he agreed
with the interviewer, undergraduates should have the right to think
as they wish, to express their own
opinions on political affairs, but
these differences in opinions should
not disrupt the organized student
body.
Choose Own Teachers

Mr. Martinez claims that Argentina, of all the South American
countries, is far more advanced educationally. He pointed out that
the higher education system, which
is exclusively maintained by the

American students aren't as
lucky as those in Argentina for, as
Mr. Martinez pointed out, the students in the South American country by popular vote select professors proposed for the faculty by the
dean. Three capable men are proposed and the students pick the one
or two they like best.
Mr. Martinez is one of the two
foreign students entered in the
February class, Lloyd Roberts, who
transferred from the University of
Wales, began work here last week,
too.
Eighteen students are registered
in the mid-year group. This number is four less than that of February, 1933. Nine are enrolled in
the College of Arts and Sciences;
five, School of Engineering; four,
School of Business Economics.

Universities from many parts of
the country are sending representatives to the lacrosse coaching school

the Hopkins method of coaching lacrosse . . . The home dribblers are
looking forward to a hard fight with
The league-leading Loyola Jesuits.
Although Hopkins was able to hand
them a defeat last year, the prospects this year are rather dim . . .

It has, been generally characteristic of the men
of socialistic sympathies who have operated on this
campus that they have been blessed with good ideas
and creditable ideals. For the most part they have
been worth listening to and have been conducive to
the intellectual uplift of the other students.
But equally characteristic has been a notorious
lack of any decent means of propagandizing. Rabid
blatancy has been the cause of antagonizing more conservatives than, probably, any other single phase of
the liberal movement. We have rather deplored the
fact that this has not come home to the liberalizers
and social reformers; they might have had much more
success with the reactionary group which seems to
predominate on all campuses.

NOBODY'S BUSINESS
By WILLIAM DE WOLFF

(1.

HAVING waited for several weeks for a chance
to see Dr. Robinson without success, I stopped at his
office again on Thursday, which was a more auspicious moment. Dr. Robinson was not immediately
visible for he was buried under a mass of papers.
Before I could ask, he commented upon the office,
and added triumphantly,"I can find anything,though".
And during the course of conversation, he proved
his point.
HE RECEIVED his A.B. at the University of
Chicago in 1898, and was a member of the third class
to be graduated. He holds the record at that stronghold of knowledge for being the youngest graduate,
for he was only seventeen when he received his first
degree. From 1898 until 1901 he was a fellow in
Greek and then went abroad for two years. He received his Ph.D. in 1904.
HE HAS taught a variety of subjects, including
Greek and Latin, as well as the history of the Greek
and Romans. Even now, while he is known for his
popular history of art course, he is teaching Greek
literature. He is an indefatigable worker, and besides teaching, running expeditions, and lecturing, he
has written a number of books, including several
translations. To date he has published sixteen volumes. He has published a series of books, now in
its eighth volume, concerning the excavations at
Olynthus. He plunged into a mass of books and
brought out the last volume.
o—o
OF COURSE, Dr. Robinson's chief concern now
is his trip to Olynthus. He is sailing February 24,
and at present he is anxiously opening every letter to
ii;crdrim.r a nice contribution.

He has lectured to the Freshman history class,
and also at the assemblies, where he made quite an impression with his slides of the ancient Greek bath
tubs. He is quite an authority on said articles.
Besides all his activities and accomplishments,
he is quite a linguist, for he speaks Turkish, Arabic,
a smattering of Chinese and Japanese, besides Latin,
Greek, German, and French.
0-0

YOU PROBABLY have seen Dr. Robinson playing tennis, and he is veritably a champion. At Syracuse last summer he won a championship, in a competition open to students and faculty. He also enjoys playing bridge and chess.
On this campaign to Greece Dr. Robinson hopes
to excavate sufficient material to make Olynthus a
real Greek Pompeii. He will return June 16.

The list of scholarships and fellowships available in .the School of
Higher Studies of the Faculty of
Philosophy has been released by the
president's office and includes stipends in zoology, Semitics, Latin,
Greek, political science, chemistry,
archaeology, education, and other
subjects.
Applications for these
awards may be secured from the
registrar's office and must be on file
with the president by the first of
March.

Student Advisors
Requested By J. E. A.
Students interested in voluntary
social service and able to devote one
night a week to the advising of girls
and boys in social, athletic, and educational activities are being requested by the Jewish Educational
Alliance, 1216 East Baltimore
Street. The alliance is a combination of settlement and community
center and has neighborhood
branches in four sections of the city.
Those interested in this type of
work are urged to consult with Gustave Bisgyer, executive director,
